components.name: Nickel
components.notes: AISC2 and A992-04a Standard lists content as < or = 0.45%. OSHA beam samples  (four I-beams that comply with ASTM A992 specifications) found content of .04, .14, .10 and .05%. "Nickel (Ni) is a powerful anti-corrosion agent, and also is one of the most important elements to improve the fracture toughness of the steel." (MetalPass) Rutgers (Material 1, Table 2) analysis of A992 steel found 0.12% nickel.

components.name: Carbon
components.notes: A992-04a Standard lists max. as 0.23%; OSHA beam samples  (four I-beams that comply with ASTM A992 specifications) found carbon content values of 0.08, 0.10, 0.16 and 0.08. Oneal: 0.23% max.  Rutgers (Material 1, Table 2) analysis of A992 steel found 0.086% carbon

components.name: Manganese
components.notes: AISC2 and A992-04a Standard lists content as 0.5-1.5%. OSHA beam samples  (four I-beams that comply with ASTM A992 specifications) found content  0.84, 0.83, 0.93 and 0.83%. Oneal lists range as 0.5% to 1.6%.  Rutgers (Material 1, Table 2) analysis of A992 steel found 1.06% manganese.

components.name: Vanadium
components.notes: A992-04a Standard lists  max as 0.05%. OSHA beam samples (four I-beams that comply with ASTM A992 specifications) found content ranging of  Rutgers (Material 1, Table 2) analysis of A992 steel found 0.012% vanadium.

components.name: Phosphorus
components.notes: AISC2 and A992 max. = 0.035%. OSHA beam samples  (four I-beams that comply with ASTM A992 specifications) found content of 0.01% for all four sampled beams.  Oneal: 0.035% max. "Phosphorus (Ρ) (has) significant detrimental effects on the ductility and weldability of the steel." (MetalPass)   Rutgers (Material 1, Table 2) analysis of A992 steel found 0.014% phosphorus.

components.name: Tin
components.notes: Gerdau: 0.08%. Rutgers (Material 1, Table 2) analysis of A992 steel found 0.011% tin.

components.name: Niobium
components.notes: A992-04a Standard lists  max as 0.15%. Oneal: 0.05% max.  Rutgers (Material 1, Table 2) analysis of A992 steel found 0.011% niobium.

components.name: Silicon
components.notes: A992 content limit: < or = 0.40%. OSHA beam samples (four I-beams that comply with ASTM A992 specifications) found content of 0.19, 0.25, 0.18, 0.16%. Oneal: 0.4% max. Rutgers (Material 1, Table 2) analysis of A992 steel found 0.19% silicon.

components.name: Nitrogen
components.notes: A992: "When vanadium is added as the only nitrogen-binding element, nitrogen shall be reported and the ratio of vanadium to nitrogen shall be 4:1 or higher if the nitrogen is greater than 0.012%."  MetalPass: "Nitrogen (Ν) will be present as well; in combination with some elements it enhances steel strength. However, free nitrogen is an important factor in the strain aging that may occur in certain steels under certain conditions; this is not considered a critical issue for structural steels."

components.name: Chromium
components.notes: AISC2 and A992-04a Standard lists content as < or = 0.35%. OSHA beam samples  (four I-beams that comply with ASTM A992 specifications) found content of 0.02, .05, .13 and .03%.  Rutgers (Material 1, Table 2) analysis of A992 steel found 0.085% chromium.

components.name: Molybdenum
components.notes: A992-04a Standard lists  max as 0.05%. OSHA beam samples (four I-beams that comply with ASTM A992 specifications) found content of 0.01, 0.03, 0.03, and 0.01%. Rutgers (Material 1, Table 2) analysis of A992 steel found 0.03% molybdenum.

components.name: Sulfur
components.notes: AISC2 lists max as 0.045%. OSHA beam samples  (four I-beams that comply with ASTM A992 specifications) found content of 0.02, 0.04, .02 and .02%. Oneal: 0.045 max.  "Phosphorus (Ρ) and sulphur (S), which have significant detrimental effects on the ductility and weldability of the steel." (MetalPass). Rutgers (Material 1, Table 2) analysis of A992 steel found 0.017% sulfur.

environmental.systemBoundary: Cradle-to-gate. Electric arc furnace (EAF) route. Includes all upstream manufacturing and transportation.
environmental.endOfLifeTreatment: 97.5% recycled (product has 113% scrap input, difference in mass results in EoL burden); 2.5% to landfill (ferro metal)

name: Structural Steel (I-beams)
description: ASTM Standard A992 grade used for structural (I) beams was first standardized in 1998 and has largely replaced A36 and other grades "because of its high yield strength and tensile strength, especially under seismic stress." (AISC)
